nodes.html:
Aims and Scope
The International Journal of Unconventional Computing offers the opportunity for rapid publication of theoretical and experimental results in non-classical computing. Specific topics include but are not limited to:

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 21
Element has sufficient color contrast of 21
Element has sufficient color contrast of 21

nodes.html: • physics of computation (e.g. conservative logic, thermodynamics of computation, reversible computing, quantum computing, collision-based computing with solitons, optical logic)

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 21

nodes.html: • chemical computing (e.g. implementation of logical functions in chemical systems, image processing and pattern recognition in reaction-diffusion chemical systems and networks of chemical reactors)

nodes.html: • bio-molecular computing (e.g. conformation based, information processing in molecular arrays, molecular memory)

nodes.html: • cellular automata as models of massively parallel computing

nodes.html: • complexity (e.g. computational complexity of non-standard computer architectures; theory of amorphous computing; artificial chemistry)

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 21

nodes.html: • logics of unconventional computing (e.g. logical systems derived from space-time behavior of natural systems; non-classical logics; logical reasoning in physical, chemical and biological systems)

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 21

nodes.html: • smart actuators (e.g. molecular machines incorporating information processing, intelligent arrays of actuators)

nodes.html: • novel hardware systems (e.g. cellular automata VLSIs, functional neural chips)

nodes.html: •  mechanical computing (e.g. micromechanical encryption, computing in nanomachines, physical limits to mechanical computation).

Editor-in-Chief: Andrew Adamatzky
ISSN: 1548-7199 (print)
ISSN: 1548-7202 (online)
80 pages/issue · 6″ x 9″
Issue Coverage: Volume 1 (2005) – Present

nodes.html:
Aims and Scope
The International Journal of Unconventional Computing offers the opportunity for rapid publication of theoretical and experimental results in non-classical computing. Specific topics include but are not limited to:

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • physics of computation (e.g. conservative logic, thermodynamics of computation, reversible computing, quantum computing, collision-based computing with solitons, optical logic)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • chemical computing (e.g. implementation of logical functions in chemical systems, image processing and pattern recognition in reaction-diffusion chemical systems and networks of chemical reactors)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • bio-molecular computing (e.g. conformation based, information processing in molecular arrays, molecular memory)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • cellular automata as models of massively parallel computing

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • complexity (e.g. computational complexity of non-standard computer architectures; theory of amorphous computing; artificial chemistry)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • logics of unconventional computing (e.g. logical systems derived from space-time behavior of natural systems; non-classical logics; logical reasoning in physical, chemical and biological systems)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • smart actuators (e.g. molecular machines incorporating information processing, intelligent arrays of actuators)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • novel hardware systems (e.g. cellular automata VLSIs, functional neural chips)

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: •  mechanical computing (e.g. micromechanical encryption, computing in nanomachines, physical limits to mechanical computation).

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Both theoretical and experimental contributions are invited.
